climbs.name: Not Forgotten
climbs.fa: John Wolfe, 1966, FFA: John Long et al., 1979

content.description: This often forgotten route is on the backside of the Hidden Tower.  Everyone sees this via the approach loop trail, and everyone forgets it just as fast.  Climb the thin discontinuous cracks/seams to the bolt anchor of Sail Away.
A few balancy face moves take you up to a secure chimney and then the top.  Downclimbing this route is quite feasible.
content.location: This is left and around the corner from Sail Away and Wild Wind.  It is in a deep chimney system which splits the two parts of the rock.

climbs.name: Split
climbs.fa: John Wolfe, Rich Wolfe, and Stu Harris, 1966

content.description: This is a vertical hand crack with one small overhang, fairly exposed.  This would be a good choice for a well-protected 5.6 trad lead.  Rappel from the top.

climbs.name: Wild Wind
climbs.fa: John Lakey, Chick Holtkamp and Randy Russell, February 1978

content.description: This is the crack just left of Sail Away.  As compared to Sail Away, it is a bit more difficult technically and a fair degree more difficult to protect, especially the traversing section close to the top.  One may escape the 5.9 crux traverse by continuing straight up, but then you'd be missing out on the best part of the route.  Belay and rap as for Sail Away.
content.protection: Standard rack to 2" with TCUs to protect thin traversing section towards the top.

content.description:
Just 10' to 12' to the right of Sail Away there is an obvious jamcrack and corner that ascends 40' or so to the shoulder of the hidden tower. This route does not top out on the summit, which is to the climber's left.

Although this is not a total waste of time (bomb) the route is rather unsatisfying and has some crumbing, gritty rock.

Overall, it's best only if done as something to bide your time as you wait for the party ahead of you to clear the Wild Wind or Sail Away routes.
content.protection: A few cams from hand-sized to large.

climbs.name: Sail Away
climbs.fa: Chick Holtkamp, Randy Russell and John Lakey, February 1978

content.description: Climb perfect hand and finger crack that virtually eats gear.  10' from the summit, move 6' left across face to flake and continue to top.  Multi-bolt anchor.  Single rope rappel to ground.
content.protection: Standard rack to 2".  If you want to go old school, just take hexes!  Three bolt anchor/rap
